Fields.DialogueText: Cursed Neizvestniy flot... come back here!
It's a lost cause - they've got too much distance on us. Best we can hope to do is get ourselves turned around and keep an eye on them.
My apologies, Kapitan. Mne zhal'.

Fields.MenuText: I'm getting a sense of déjà vu here...
You did the important part and sent her sprinting with her tail between her legs. All she did was live to lose another day.
The problem is you're just too nice, Parizhskaya Kommuna. You need to learn to taunt Morganas better. I'm sure they'd stick around longer if you did.

Fields.DialogueText: I really am sorry.
You have a point, Kapitan. If the Neizvestniy flot have a virtue, it is persistence.
I don't think being nice is my problem, Kapitan. I believe in letting let my actions speak for me, so my... verbal arsenal isn't as effective as others.
You know the routine... we keep her in sight as long as we can and put the word out.
Yes, Kapitan.
And if you get the chance, pass along to our chief engineer that I want to set up a meeting. Maybe if we put our heads together, we can think of ways to increase your speed.
I... yes, Kapitan.
It looks like a lot of them this time.
Not more than we can overcome, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Damn. The second group's pulling away...
Parizhskaya Kommuna?
*yawns*
Da, Kapitan?
I spoke to the chief engineer. It seems you didn't relay my message.
Ah. I apologize, Kapitan. I was kept so busy, our paths never crossed. Mne zhal'.
I see. Well, I spoke to her and set up a meeting at...
*frowns*
They have returned.
You mean the Morganas?
Da.

Fields.MenuText: She didn't stay away long. I'd call her a giddy masochist, except that would make us sadists.
If I didn't know you, I'd say that timing was convenient.
I have a message for her, too. Think you can free up your schedule and deliver it for me promptly this time?

Fields.DialogueText: She could also be probing to see how much combat we're willing to stomach. If she thinks I will grow weary after one or two exchanges, she is sorely mistaken.
Thanks to the other First Comrades, I was aware she was still somewhere in the area, but not exactly sure where. Until now.
Absolutely, Kapitan. I'll inscribe it on all my shells to ensure your message reaches her in a timely fashion.
I still want to have that meeting later. But first things first...
@BATTLE
Parizhskaya Kommuna, I've been looking all over...
Watch your step, Kapitan. The light here is out.
I can see that. What are you doing? Changing a lightbulb or something?
Replacing the bulb. By myself, I will add.

Fields.MenuText: That's typically the number of Belles that are needed for that job, the last time I checked...
It sounds like you've heard that joke before...
I have absolute faith in your ability, Parizhskaya Kommuna.

Fields.DialogueText: I think so too. Although I have heard of one or two of the more competitive - and creative - members of the Fleet attempting the task with only half a Comrade....
It didn't seem very funny when I was asked the first time. I still don't get it.
Thank you, Kapitan.
Since you are closer, would you turn on the lights?
Sure. Ready?
Da. Ready.
*lights pop*
This... may require more help.
Don't worry. Asking about manpower to replace a lightbulb is one thing, but anyone who ever asked how many electricians it takes to track down a short wanted a serious answer.
@BATTLE
Parizhskaya Kommuna?
Da?
It's about time to go meet the chief engineer for that meeting...
Kapitan, may I make a suggestion?

Fields.MenuText: Suggest away, Parizhskaya Kommuna.
This has something to do with that meeting, I trust? If not...
You can suggest whatever you want, Parizhskaya Kommuna. I make no guarantees I'll act on it...

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo, Kapitan.
It does, absolutely.
I see. The thing is...
I was wondering if Pompa Petrenko should also attend this meeting.
Our political officer? I don't see what he could bring to the table on a physical issue...
While it is true he doesn't know much about the inner workings of battleships and rubber-stamps your orders by and large, it might be a point of courtesy to invite him.
That's true. There's no real reason to keep him out of the loop, and who knows? He may have some gleam of insight that we keep overlooking because it's obvious. So, where is he now?
Where he normally is when we are in rough seas.
... Meaning the head. Even if we managed to drag him out, I'm sure he'd be in no condition or mood. Are you sure we can't just have a preliminary meeting without him?
But he can't provide any potential insight if he isn't there...
Fine. If I didn't know better...
Kapitan?
Never mind. I want to know the minute he isn't trying to turn his stomach inside out.
Yes, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
When I heard you were changing the lights in here I had no idea that meant adding new fixtures.
The short is proving problematic to find, even for me.
That's actually impressive.
It doesn't happen often, I'll agree. It left me with three options. I have chosen to bypass the existing wiring and install a new, temporary light.
What were the other two?
Rip out the existing wiring and replace the whole circuit...
While we're at sea? I agree, that level of fix would cause more problems than it would solve. And the third option?
Curse the darkness.

Fields.MenuText: Miners' helmet lights would work too.
The darkness wouldn't be the only thing cursed, Parizhskaya Kommuna. Hatches and ladders are painful enough when you can see them.
Adversity builds character.

Fields.DialogueText: I hadn't thought of that. Consider it a fourth option.
I agree. The doctor sees enough bruised shins as it is.
It would also be a rather harsh means to build better memory of my layout, too. Not everyone can navigate my decks in their sleep... *yawn* like I can...
This can go on the list of things to do the next time we can string a couple of days in port together, I guess.
Do me a favor and remember to schedule yourself some rest when that happens, all right? You could end up needing to go out to sea for a break from work.
... I will remember, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Ahhh. Eto budet tak khorosho.
Stay focused!
@BATTLE
All right! Our chief engineer is on the way to give her post-combat report, the seas are relatively calm and our political officer is chewing on candied ginger for good measure.
All we need is you and I and... what are you doing?
*yawns*
I am assisting with the gun crew's rotation of the barrels on my Obukhovskii Pattern guns.
I can see that, Parizhskaya Kommuna. Why now, though? Did something go wrong with them?
Nyet. I have noticed a slight but growing decrease in accuracy from my fore turret, though... the product of normal combat wear and tear.
I don't always get to bring them all to bear, and my barrels wear disproportionately, so I thought I'd switch the fore turret barrels with the ones from my midship's turrets.

Fields.MenuText: Accuracy is a good thing and rotating them like that makes sense. Do you have to do it right this minute?
I like accuracy too, and the midship barrels do get less use on the chase, but we still use them. You're simply prolonging a relining for the forward barrels for a little while longer.
I'd like more warning when you take it into your head to play musical chairs with the big guns, Parizhskaya Kommuna.

Fields.DialogueText: Prepare the sled in summer, and cart in winter. It would be best to do it during the calm between combat, yes? I thought that now was as good a time as any.
It also means relining more than just the forward turret barrels as well.
My apologies, Kapitan.
Are you feeling all right? You look... flushed. Hold still...
Kapitan, wait...
Ouch! Good grief, Parizhskaya Kommuna! You're scorching hot!
I'm sorry, Kapitan! You reached out before I could warn you...
That's it! Disarm and see me in sick bay!
But...
No buts! It's a wonder your personal ordinance hasn't already gone off...
... Yes, Kapitan.
But I'd prefer to be on patrol for the Neizvestniy flot rather than portbound after every protracted battle... and just to refresh a fraction of what I'm armed with.
How are you holding together, Parizhskaya?
You don't even need to ask me, Kapitan.
Oh, yes, I do. I'm not at all convinced that you should even be on your feet in the state you're in.
And if I were a normal member of the crew, you might be right. But...
I know. Just take care of yourself, okay?
Da. Thank you.
How's the bandage, Captain? Comfortable?
I've definitely had worse jobs done.
... I request permission to enter the Infirmary.

Fields.MenuText: Are you disarmed?
I told you to disarm, not prepare yourself for a firing squad. You don't have to be that formal, Parizhskaya Kommuna. Come in.
With that temperature of yours, you are the last person on this ship that needs to ask to enter the Sick Bay.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Kapitan.
... Yes, Kapitan.
Very well, Kapitan.
Kapitan.... Your burn...
It's nothing serious.
The Kapitan will live. You, on the other hand, have some explaining to do, First Comrade. What's this I hear about an engineering meeting? And my being added to it?
Pomplit Peterenko... and Chief Engineer Dmitrieff...
You've dragged this out long enough, Gray Horse. This fever of yours... it's the boilers, isn't it?
What?
... Da. Mne zhal'.
Well, that's that. Meeting here makes things simpler... Captain, I'm going to have to cool the boilers. Expect power for no more than eight knots.
For how long?
Ask the First Comrade.
Permission granted.
... It may depend on how the next battle goes.
Fantastic.
@BATTLE
Parizhskaya Kommuna, what's going on?
How do I explain...
How about you start at the beginning, and when you come to the end stop.
Go ahead and use small words too, while you're at it. The less technical the better.
Very well. I am an old ship.

Fields.MenuText: I prefer to use the term "well seasoned."
You're new to me, Parizhskaya Kommuna.
You can say that again...

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate the sentiment, Kapitan.
Thank you, Kapitan.
Over the years, I have been modified. A lot. Thanks to all-oil boilers and modern turbines, I have not sacrificed my speed much, despite the added weight.
But... it has made me somewhat... unbalanced.
So the one with no sea legs is sent to sea on a ship that rolls at the drop of a hat. Typical.
I'm aware of your stability issues. If memory serves, you're due for a retrofit to address that.
So you were aware of it. Given... given that timetable did not include the arrival of the Neizvestniy flot, is that retrofit still as planned?
Wait, are you saying this is about your scheduled visit to the dry dock?
That should help, but it will take a while. I brought gloves for the meantime.
And what do you know about all this?
I know that even under the best conditions, the bricks in the First Comrade's boilers would eventually need to be replaced. With the arrival of the the Neizvestniy flot...
Best conditions were blown to bits with her first salvo.
Yes. Since then, it's been "maximum speed" here, "maximum speed" there, and don't spare the boilers, comrade. That takes its toll, Captain.
I asked our gray horse here about them recently. Figured if they were getting to be too worn out, we could call it as good a time as any to head in for her refit, you see?
Kill two birds with one stone. This is starting to become clear now.
... They weren't that bad when she asked.
You called it a slight case of heartburn, First Comrade...

Fields.MenuText: I'm starting to get heartburn here...
Her condition affects us all. I need to know about these things in the future.
You apparently weren't aware of our Belle's gift for the understatement.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm an engineer, Captain. Unless you're a Comrade of the Fleet, I'm not a doctor.
Duly noted, Captain.
I am now, Captain.
What's your assessment now?
Without properly inspecting a dozen cold boilers? Gray Horse would give you a faster answer than I can.
Parizhskaya Kommuna?
If I focus on my boilers... and only them... there should be no lasting effects.
I see. Then is it possible to rebrick while we're at sea, Chief?
Kapitan?
If we had the materials - and it would mean taking boilers down one, maybe two at a time. And Neizvestniy flot or no, they would stay down until ready, Captain.
It sounds like you're asking for a drawn-out, messy procedure, Kapitan.
So be it. It would give you ample time to explain why risking this much stress was better than a scheduled trip to the drydock, Parizhskaya Kommuna.
Yes, Kapitan.
For Grey Horse here, I will make it possible.
How goes it?
It is hot down here and I have to concentrate on something I'm not allowed to help with. I have to be careful with the quilt I was given or I run the risk of scorching it.
If I wasn't an atheist, I'd say this was Hell.
... An atheist. Okay, I'll bite... you can clearly thank shipbuilders for your hull's existence, but how do you explain yourself?
*smiles proudly*
I, Kapitan, am the Will of the People. The desire of the defenseless for protection against the oppressors of this world.
If you say so.
*yawns*
I know so. It is what Comrade Stalin has called the Comrades of the Fleet, at any rate...
You aren't sleeping well again.
It has not been easy keeping this from you.
Talk to me, then. What has you worried about the retrofit? You take to repairs with relish...
Repairs are one thing. Repairs fix what is broken. What I already have. This retrofit... it isn't something as simple as mounting anti-aircraft guns to the tops of my turrets.
Alterations on this scale will put me in dry dock for months. The Protection Force has so few Comrades of the Fleet as it is, Kapitan.
I don't feel I have the luxury of time to be out of action that long.

Fields.MenuText: The Fleet would lose a lot more of our time if you capsized in bad weather.
It wouldn't be a walk in the park, but the Fleet would manage.
I know you're more than willing to do your part for the Fleet. ...And then some. Let the rest of the Fleet help you out for a change.

Fields.DialogueText: *frowns* ... I wouldn't...
I know they would, Kapitan. I'm not arrogant enough to believe I'm irreplaceable. I just don't like being the cause of extra troubles.
One can't wash the black dog all the way to whiteness. It's just who I am, Kapitan.
That estimate was made for a ship without a Belle, before the Morganas showed up. Between your assistance and a dock full of shipfitters who want you back on patrol?
Back where you stand between them and the Morganas? You'd be surprised how fast things get done with that level of purpose.
*ALARM*
Morganas...
Kapitan, I take back what I said. I may be an atheist, but this is definitely Hell.
@BATTLE
No ship is unsinkable, Parizhskaya Kommuna.
I didn't expect this from you.
Expect what from me, Kapitan?
Pacing.
I'm not pacing.
Yes, you are. Either that, or you're going around in circles.
I'm not going around in circles. I'm-
I'm pacing...

Fields.MenuText: Told you.
That's quite the level of concentration you have there.
Don't fret. I see it as your subconscious still on the prowl for work. Now that I think about it, I'd be more worried if you just sat quietly in a corner.

Fields.DialogueText: So you did, Kapitan. I apologize for doubting you.
I'll make a mental note to avoid ladders and hatches. ... And gangplanks... docks...
I see...
Did Chief Dmitrieff give you the news yet?
*yawns*
News?
We're heading for port to pick up more bricks. She says we'll be in long enough to put out all but a couple boilers, just in case.
That will give you a break from this, let you two prioritize the worst of the undone boilers and try to double the pace.
Heading for port.
It shouldn't take so much out of you when we head out again, so bear with it for just a little while longer.
... To pick up more bricks.
... Right. Unless we run into Morganas it won't be much...
*ALARM*
Damnation. What was it the Pomplit said last time?
*yawn* Speak of the gray wolf, the gray wolf heads your way.
Put up with it Cossack, and you'll be an ataman.
@BATTLE
You look better.
*yawns*
You even sound better.
I do not think I will feel better until you allow me work privileges again, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: How soon you get back to work depends on how much rest you get. Even you have to admit how much all that took out of you.
I said you look and sound better, not back to your old self.
No means no. And if you keep pestering me about it, I'll banish you to a deck chair for champagne and caviar hors d'oeuvres.

Fields.DialogueText: I would say the Ice Cruise took more out of me than this, but I do not think I sound convincing right now.
And I wonder if I will able to get back to being my "old self" so long as work is denied me. Do you see the conundrum I am in?
Kapitan, I fear I will go crazy without being allowed something to do. It's something that I dislike about refits, actually.
Oh?
There is so much waiting for one step to finish before the next can be started. Like waiting for a boiler to be cold before it can be overhauled, for instance.
Nice try, Parizhskaya Kommuna.
You will have to explain what you mean by that later, Kapitan.
*yawns*
In the meantime, I will get some rest after I have convinced the Neizvestniy flot this is not where she wants to be.
@BATTLE
That's the last boiler?
It will be, when it is cold enough to work on.
This is what I meant about refits, Captain. Being stalled before I can even start? It makes me crazy.

Fields.MenuText: You are the last person to find absolutely nothing to do within range of this ship.
Waiting for boilers to cool doesn't stop you from ripping out and replacing a faulty light circuit. You know it too, since I see those tools peeking out of your pouch...
It's me that's going to go crazy if I have to assign someone to literally sit on you before you take a break.

Fields.DialogueText: I see your point. I suppose when my spaces aren't either a work in progress or spotless, I could be of some use on the docks...
... You noticed those. You are right, Kapitan. Maybe while I'm waiting, I should organize a list of things I can do while I'm waiting!
Please don't do that. I wouldn't want to drive you crazy.
How does this sound... if progress was that bottlenecked, everything else was spotless, visitors were restricted and you could play the bandeon as well as your teacher...
I'd arrange to get another ship in for refit close enough for you to help out.
I doubt I will ever outdo Comrade Komelkov on the bandeon, but...you'd do that? For me?
I would be watching the progress on your hull like a hawk, though. The minute it even looked like they were trying to slack off so you could stick around longer...
Trust me, Kapitan. I would not let that happen either.
I trust you. Now, do me a favor and try counting bricks or something to get a nap in. Okay?
... Da. Yes, Kapitan.
*whispers* I would never put down my duties at sea any longer than absolutely necessary, though. I couldn't face my sister if I did.
@BATTLE
... It would also take far more than a single sailor to restrain me, and I'd feel bad about taking up their time when we could all be doing something more constructive instead.
What's this, a conspiracy?
Hardly, Kapitan. Unless you are referring to the one you share with Chief Dmitrieff and the First Comrade, leaving me in the dark about this "retrofit"...
I thought I would find a copy of the proposal and show him, Kapitan.
You are a transplant from the army, aren't you? Sorry about that.
Better late than never.
Here it is.
Let's see... hmm... more deck armor I understand. But... these bulges along your flanks? Just to make you more stable?
They're anti-torpedo armor as well. A torpedo hits the bulge and it absorbs the force and fragments, instead of my hull.
And what of the torpedo tubes you have down there now?
Removed. Is this what you're dreading? Not just the time it will take, but the results?
Not the results, exactly. Torpedoes for more protection and stability is a reasonable tradeoff. The People have given it their blessing.
The People's Commissar for Defense, you mean. They look bad enough on paper... do they even work?
It's sound technology. Several other nations have used them to beef up the armor on ships her age.
... It still doesn't change the fact that torpedoes wouldn't be the only thing the First Comrade would trade. You aren't exactly skimming across the tops of waves, as it is.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe she would be by now if I could get you two and the Chief in the same room for once...
Parizhskaya Kommuna doesn't have to be the fastest in the Fleet. She will be just fine if she's faster than the slowest Morgana.
No one was before the Great War, Pompolit.

Fields.DialogueText: My apologies, Kapitan. I would have invited her to help explain the proposal to Pompa Petrenko if she wasn't asleep.
You are very wise, Kapitan. Those are truly inspirational words!
The Kapitan is right, Pompa. As much as it pains me to say it, at one time I was warship fit for a Tzar. Times have clearly changed, Comrade.
... Kapitan. One of the Neizvestniy flot has been sighted.
The proposal isn't going anywhere. We can discuss this later.
@BATTLE
If you're putting that copy of the proposal away, I take it our political officer understands it now.
He understands the logic to it, even if he does not agree with it. "This proposal is incomplete since it doesn't include a light cruiser towboat as part of your equipment" is what he said...
Very funny. You said earlier the results weren't the issue to you. What's wrong then?
This would not be the first time I've had profound modifications. But... it would be the first one I've undergone since becoming a First Comrade. Who knows what will happen?

Fields.MenuText: It's not like you to fear change, Parizhskaya Kommuna. You're usually such an advocate and instigator of it.
We aren't going to know what happens until it does, I guess. But... there's always a first time for everything.
You said you're the Will of the People, right? Worst case, the people here merely will you to get back up and rub a little dirt on it.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not change I fear, Kapitan. What I fear is changing so much that I'm not me anymore. Of being warped so much that I become unrecognisable to you... and to myself.
Don't wake trouble while it sleeps quietly. It's very true, but easier said than done.
Where there's a will there's a way. Da... Then I will hold you to that, Kapitan, if I am forced to return to my hull and somehow forget how to take form again.
I understand that your hull is important and that changes to it could spell changes to you. If this was frivolous we wouldn't even be having this conversation.
... And if you were just launched I'd also have second thoughts. But you are a veteran, Parizhskaya Kommuna.
I believe your wealth of experience will preserve the "you" that I know. You'll adapt.
So you think my age may be a benefit in this case. ... I will think about what you have said, Kapitan.
Have you spoken to any other Belles? Maybe someone else has had something this extensive and could provide you with insight.
Good idea. I have not, but there are one or two that I can think of. Maybe I will ask them.
Please do.
@BATTLE
Parizhskaya Kommuna...
*yawns*
Hello, Kapitan. I know you want me to rest, but hunger was interfering with sleep. I thought a solid plate of makaroni po-flotski would work wonders, so I came here to have some.
The crew galley.
Da.
During the height of meal services.
And that's quite the amount you've made. It looks like enough to feed eight or nine hundred ravenous sailors.
... Give or take...

Fields.MenuText: Is there enough for a Belle, eight or nine hundred ravenous sailors and one captain?
Remind me never to bother asking "have you brought enough for everybody."
Grab your own plate and find a chair.

Fields.DialogueText: Certainly! Give me just a moment here...
It would be heartless to eat my fill before the hungry, Kapitan.
I suppose the line is beginning to thin...
I really am hungry. But I also considered this a good way to show my gratitude to these people... especially after all I have unintentionally put them through lately...
They're a resilient bunch.
Da. It fills my heart with joy to be in spaces where they are gathered. To hear the banter and laughter, the songs and quarrels. Even before...
... Even before I was recommissioned, I did not take my crew for granted. Now, I'm even more appreciative of those who sail with me.
I'll bet.
... Some of the Neizvestniy flot are coming.
Looks like they came at a bad time...
They did.
@BATTLE
So it does get quiet around here from time to time.
Da, it can. Especially so, when it's down to just shipfitters and a skeleton crew.
A dockyard in full swing is hardly quiet, but I see your point.
If only I could choose to go elsewhere...

Fields.MenuText: The materials are already waiting for you at the Baltic Works. It would be wasteful to not use them.
Unfortunately, that would look more suspicious, not less.
Well, you can't.

Fields.DialogueText: I doubt that would happen, Kapitan. If they were not used on me, they would be diverted to another. I speak with experience there.
I would like to know what less suspicious looks like, then.
I doubt there is any ship that enjoys the feeling of being in dry dock after her hull has touched water. I dislike feeling so... vulnerable.
We're still needed, Kommuna. If we weren't, there would be no reason to add more protection to you. As soon as you're finished, you'll be back to business as usual. Trust me.
Da. Of course, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Captain. And our Grey Horse, too. Is this a time to fetch the Cossack, or do I give my report and go on my way?
Chief Dmitrieff. I hadn't planned to brainstorm about our current speeds, but if our political officer is available...
He is. I'll go and get him, if you'd like.

Fields.MenuText: That would be a big help, thanks.
If you want to include him for his wit and wisdom and not as a means to stall the conversation, then be my guest.
You can try, anyway... I'm beginning to have my doubts this little Committee can get higher than an attendance of three. Ever.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll be right back with Pompa Petrenko, then.
My apologies, Kapitan. I'll return with him shortly. I may have used him badly, but I also meant everything I said when I suggested adding him.
Pompa Petrenko said the same thing just the other day.
I've been meaning to ask you something, Chief. You keep calling Parizhskaya Kommuna "Grey Horse." What's behind that?
Captain, there is a saying: "Put everything onto the grey horse, he'll bear anything."
So long as she is willing to shoulder any burden, then Grey Horse it is for her.
She's been balking at the refit, though...
Does that mean you consider it a burden?
... She certainly has brought up a lot of valid concerns.
And has she refused to go through with it? Or does she voice her concerns only because she fell into her own snare and you found out?
What are you trying to say, Chief?
*ALARM*
Neizvestniy flot...*Huff*...To port. *Huff* Not my fault. *Huff*
@BATTLE
Parizhskaya Kommuna, the Chief sent me a formal request for something. When I asked her why, she said it was a question for you to answer.
I wasn't aware of it, but if Chief Dmitrieff thinks I can provide an answer for you, I will do my utmost to provide one. What is she requesting? Something difficult?
Not difficult. Just... unusual. Before you are refitted, she wants to make a brief detour and visit some barracks hulk that's on our way into the Baltic Works.
She also wants us to get close enough for you to be able to go aboard too, but only if you choose to.
... I see. I have an idea of her intentions, then.

Fields.MenuText: Any particular reason why? Do you know some of the sailors living there or something?
Out with it, then. What's this all about?
I'm still in the dark here. She didn't even give me the name of this hulk she wants to visit, just a location.

Fields.DialogueText: I have had a long career, so it is possible. But... for this, the visit is to see the ship herself.
I believe before the refit process begins, Chief Dmitrieff wants to give me an opportunity to visit with family. I know that barracks ship, Kapitan.
I suspect that was intentional, or else you might have recognized the ship for who she is.
She is my little sister, Frunze.
@BATTLE
Found you.
Kapitan? But... I was not hiding.

Fields.MenuText: Not when you're in the middle of bandoneon practice, that's for sure.
But you have been avoiding me, now that I know what to look for. I know family can be a touchy subject, so don't worry. I won't pry.
What have you been doing, then?

Fields.DialogueText: *smiles proudly* I have been upgraded from the anguished cries of a hugged goose, to a skipping record. Such an improvement!
If you thought I was avoiding you, I apologize. I have been searching my feelings lately, and I let the direction of work dictate where I was going. As for family...
Thinking about the past.
I appreciate your concern, Kapitan, but please don't misunderstand me. I am proud of all of my sisters. Frunze is no exception. There is no finer example of giving to the cause than hers.
Tell me about her.
Well, she received her commission next, after I did... her name was Poltava then. The four of us worked together during the Great War and the Revolution, so we shared a lot of memories.
She loved speed.
Loves...
I understand.
*ALARM*
Duty calls. But I do want to continue this conversation later, if you're up for it.
I will be, Kapitan. Thank you.
@BATTLE
Can I have you put down that paintbrush temporarily? I could use some help here...
My apologies, Kapitan! What have I overlooked that you need attending to?
I have two cups of tea here, and I can't savor them both before they get cold...
I see. Then fear not, Kapitan! I will attend to this mug, and we will have them done in no time.
Mine is still just a bit too warm to drink just yet, though. Perhaps you could continue your story where we last left off...
Unfortunately there is not much to tell. For a while, Frunze, Oktabrina and I were put in reserve. ... A fire started in Frunze's forward boiler room.
She was a shell of her former self when Marat and I left for Kronstadt.
But she is patient, that sister of mine. ... And generous too. Her parts have maintained the rest of us...
Hold it right there. Are you saying that she was cannibalized for spare parts?!
That's not how the Party describes it...

Fields.MenuText: I'll just bet it doesn't. That takes on a whole new meaning where you Belles are concerned.
I owe her a debt of gratitude then, for what she's given to you.
Generous to a fault. It must run in your family.

Fields.DialogueText: I owe one to you too, Kapitan. I know I do.
I will take that as a compliment.
Even now Frunze is a commissioned member of the Red Fleet. Over the years, there have been several proposals that would make her a more active participant, but...
For now, she serves in the humble role of floating barracks.
It won't happen to you.
Kapitan?
It's easy to think, isn't it? That what happened to her could happen to you, too.
What happened to her won't happen to you. With your work ethic, you pass white-glove inspections with ease.
I'm just setting a good example...
And your Chief Engineer clearly knows Frunze's story. She will definitely do everything in her power to ensure history doesn't repeat itself. And last but not least
Even if the worst case scenario occurs and something bad does happen... you can do something about it. You are not helpless, not as she was then.
Da.... Yes, you're right. Thank you, Kapitan.
When was the last time you paid Frunze a visit?
It has been a while, I confess. If she were able, she would be the first to scold me about it... but... it is difficult to see her when I am still able to go to sea and she isn't.
Then you need to visit her more often, Parizhskaya Kommuna. You can't be scolded if you don't.
*smiles*
Spasibo, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
I will, I promise! Hurry back soon!
Where are those kids off to? Hopefully you haven't made a promise you can't keep. We won't be here in port that long.
Kapitan! Not to worry, my promise to them is to be brave.

Fields.MenuText: I thought that went without saying.
They were worried you were a coward? You?!
It sounds like their definition of courage has a high bar, if they're scolding a Belle that charges Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: Now, now, Kapitan. A stout heart does not come from arms and armor, but is a beautiful, powerful thing all its own. The wicked and corrupt forget that at their peril.
Many of our battles are far out to sea, as they should be. That means there are fewer witnesses however, so much of our valor goes unsung.
It was not my service to they were encouraging me about, but my own personal courage.
This all came about when I was carving for them.
*yawns*
My knife slipped and I cut myself a little. They were impressed that I did not cry, but wanted assurances that I would see the doctor later, so that I do not get lockjaw.
"You will get a shot," they said, "but be brave."
Somehow, I doubt you need to worry about that.
Perhaps not for lockjaw. But how different is this from what waits for me? They are correct
I see. So what's your reward for keeping your promise? A lollipop?
*smiles proudly*
Broken bicycles. My first attempt to make one from scratch was no good. If I had a couple that previously worked though, I'm sure I could puzzle out how to make a proper one.
It will give me another project to keep me busy, so that I don't run out of things to do. Now if you will excuse me, I must be brave like a dreadnaught and get shot before they return.
@BATTLE
Not that I mind, Kapitan. The heartfelt smiles of the free are more reward to me than a mountain of medals.
... Well?
INPF Battleship Parizshkaya Kommuna requests permission to board the Soviet ship Frunze.

Fields.MenuText: Quit hiding behind formality and get over there, you chicken.
Well, she didn't say 'Denied,' so...
You probably don't need to be so formal, Parizhskaya Kommuna. It sounds like you're bragging and I know you don't intend to sound like that at all.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Kapitan...
I will take that as a good sign as well.
It does? But I don't want to be rude and just board her, like it's a right I'm entitled to...
... Kapitan, some of the Neizvestniy flot are near.
Looks like the reunion gets delayed temporarily.
@BATTLE
Let's try this again.
Da.
Little sister ... I would like to come on board ... if you do not mind...
There now. Was that so bad?
No, Kapitan.
Well then. I can tour the rest of the ship with the Chief and give you two some time to yourselves if you'd like...
You are kind, Kapitan, but that is not necessary. Frunze is not a First Comrade, and I... there is so much to say and our time so limited that I don't know where to start.
Ah! But I thought I would play her a lullaby that I've learned, to show her my progress on the bandeon!
That sounds sweet. What have you learned?
*yawns*
Kalinka.
... That's the most manic lullaby in the world.
Not in my case, but I am working on it. Now, I will just sit here, and...
Parizhskaya Kommuna?
*zzz*
Thank you, Frunze.
Have the stars aligned somewhere? My mate of political affairs, chief engineer and Belle? All in one place and time?
Well, of course the stars align as we near our destination. This little committee has become obsolete, after all.
@BATTLE
... You've heard the news, then.
Nyet. I was about to make a cunning and provocative declaration, but I think perhaps you have a more urgent one.
Kapitan?
The scheduled refit is no longer scheduled.
What?
I just got word. The Morganas made a push on the Gulf of Riga, and the Soviet Union's Baltic assets... well, reading between the lines, I gather it wasn't pretty.
They don't want Parizhskaya Kommuna tied up in drydock, and they have urgent need of the intended materiel elsewhere.
What about the gulf?
The Morganas were repulsed. Significant civilian casualties in Jūrmala, though I don't know the numbers. Bomber strikes for no obvious reason.
Neutrality Fleet minesweepers apparently have their work cut out for them now. And Morgana mines are....
I've heard stories.
Are we needed there? Can we help?
No. We have our own mission, at this point.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry, Parizhskaya.
So let's get to it.
Care to make your cunning and provocative declaration now, Pompolit Petrenko? The floor is yours.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll make do, Kapitan. Don't ever doubt it.
Da. Let's.
I'm afraid the war has once again made one of intended speeches redundant, Kapitan. I'm sorry to disappoint you all, but we might as well get back to work.
So that's where the gremlins caused that short...
Gremlins?
What else could it be, Kapitan? The First Comrades from the Royal Navy were warned about such imps by their pilots, and they have told me to be on the lookout.
My floatplanes must have picked some up somewhere and brought them back...

Fields.MenuText: I think someone's pulling your leg.
Really. And did they offer any advice on how to get rid of "gremlins" if you encountered them?
More likely, you picked up your "gremlin" from the Morganas, given how shoddy they look.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? Is there one on my boot? Where? I don't see it...
Regular and thorough inspections along with diligent maintenance.
You may be onto something, Kapitan. Issues attributable to gremlins often coincide with combat...
I suppose you were assuming this would get fixed in the refit.
There's no point in crying about it, Kapitan. But, yes, I put this task off, and now it's time to make it right...
I wouldn't call overhauling the boilers putting it off.
While that is true, the short didn't fix itself... and there is no time like the present.
... Unless the Neizvestniy flot are around, that is...
@BATTLE
Then you don't have to worry about "gremlins," Parizhskaya Kommuna. You do all that already.
@BATTLE
You're still pensive, aren't you? It's not like you to hang your head on the rail like that.
Parizhskaya? Are you all right?
Parizhskaya Kommuna, are you listening? Is there something over the side?
Oh, Kapitan! Come and look! Barnacles! It has not been that long since my last servicing and look at them all!
If there is anything in the sea that symbolizes the parasitic bourgeois class upon the proletariat, it's barnacles! They are likely holding back my efforts for speed, Kapitan.
There's some, but I don't think that's anywhere near enough...
They will be excised from my hull with all haste. I need to get my scrub brush... maybe a spare just in case...
My apologies, Kapitan. You were speaking to me a moment ago...?
It was nothing. Carry on, Parizhskaya Kommuna.
Yes, Kapitan!
So, I've received some clarification from our friends in Moscow.
You make it sound like piracy.
Piracy? Surely it's better to say "a pragmatic situational allocation of discovered resources."
I'm sorry if I don't sound totally enthused. It's basically good news - but I've got mixed feelings about being told to forage for parts.

Fields.MenuText: It's demeaning, really.
I mean, I'd do it anyway, but I'm happier when Command isn't in the loop.
Here I've been promising you that you have more institutional support than your sister did-

Fields.DialogueText: And suddenly I'm telling you that if you need new armor we have to pry it off a Morgana wreck ourselves.
*cough*
Oh, that's not true. And I'm grateful that the resources of the state are going to those who need them most.
Kapitan, I'm not offended. Resources are going where they're needed, and I'm still free to serve. I couldn't ask for better.
Well, that said, keep your eyes open. If we secure anything you can use, don't be shy about letting us know. The Chief could use a creative challenge now and then.
You can be the one to tell her that.
Kapitan? Spasibo - but, look to starboard.
Right. I see them.
They may not be prepared to pay for anything, but we're cleared for a refit according to Neutrality Fleet protocols - so we can install anything we can grab for ourselves.
*sigh*
Now, if you two will excuse me for a moment, I believe my legs could do with a bit of a stretch.
Of course.
Enjoy.
... I'm sorry if you're disappointed, Kapitan. You and Chief Dmitrieff. I know you hoped the Grey Horse could be made to run faster.
I can only promise that I will redouble my efforts, and-
We wanted to make things easier for you, Parizhskaya. Working yourself into the ground - so to speak - is exactly the opposite of the intended effect.
I don't feel like I'm "working myself into the ground." My heart actually feels lighter than it has in a very long time.
Yes?
Da.
Though, I'll confess, after spending so long worrying how the refit would change me, I was beginning to get curious.
Well, hopefully you'll be excited when we actually make it happen. In the meantime-
Not *excited*, exactly, but curious.
